This is related to [#!/osrf/subt/issues/97/potential-issue-with-x3-x4-control-via](#!/osrf/subt/issues/97/potential-issue-with-x3-x4-control-via) and [#!/osrf/subt/issues/163/any-help-on-how-to-fly-uavs-inside-tunnel](#!/osrf/subt/issues/163/any-help-on-how-to-fly-uavs-inside-tunnel)

When applying a static upward force to the X4/X3 drones, I have noticed that drones will drift forward slowly.   I am wondering why they do not hover in place.  This leads me to a few other questions about the controls.

* What is the future plan for the UAV  control?  Is cmd\_force going to be the permanent method, will it be reverting back to the waypoint method eventually, or will it change to something else in the future?
* Is the cmd\_force being applied to the center of mass of the UAV, and the current controller adjust motor speeds as necessary?
* If the requested applied force is in the x direction, will the current controller adjust for any rotations of the drone, or do we need to account for that in our control model? 
* Is there a method for us to control motor speeds directly, if not, can that be opened up?

‌

‌

When applying a static upward force to the X4/X3 drones, I have noticed that drones will drift forward slowly. I am wondering why they do not hover in place. This leads me to a few other questions about the controls.

  • What is the future plan for the UAV control? Is cmd_force going to be the permanent method, will it be reverting back to the waypoint method eventually, or will it change to something else in the future?
  • Is the cmd_force being applied to the center of mass of the UAV, and the current controller adjust motor speeds as necessary?
  • If the requested applied force is in the x direction, will the current controller adjust for any rotations of the drone, or do we need to account for that in our control model?
  • Is there a method for us to control motor speeds directly, if not, can that be opened up?
